sp.p: So! now will I instantly home, and perswade him, that all is false, and onely the motions of envy. Come my Lord, shall we go—Dorel! bid the Coachman come round to St. Iames's Gate.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What is that Fellow? I never saw him before.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Sir Arthur entertain'd him in his service to day to look to his accompt.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And, brush his antiquities—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Never was man so besotted: he dares not sleep o'nights for fear of Thieves.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Dam him and his old Imaginations: Let us mind our own business: Come, let's to the Mulberry Garden▪ I ha' not treated you this week: methinks we live already as we were Marry'd, not a word of Love in a whole Scene of Discourse.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: 'Tis better i'th' Heart than in the Tongue; besides, from a Man of quality, Love has so strange a sound: no, in my opinion, the Eyes are the best Orator, and now and then the Serious Look, with a short sigh for a Prologue.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thus! ha!

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: And sometimes the exalting the hand to the lip, with a short Kiss and away.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Now I consider better, I shall have occasion to be punctual to an hour: My Lord, prithee lend me your Watch: hah—blood and death, What do I see?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Return'd agen! this was a Curs'd trick of fate.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ungrateful Traitress! now I plainly see (all I have heard is true.) Perfidious Celia: more false than Crocodills, that mourn the slain, and yet delight to kill 'em: Do you not blush? Are you so arm'd with impudence, this object cannot startle? yea, this beguil'd object, that bath'd his passion in warm Tears of blood, and laid it at your feet, deceitful Celia.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Celia! What a mistake is this, by heaven my Friend's mad.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Now Wit assist me, or I'm lost. Mad—Why d'ee not fee't? look, look how his eyes rowle; how pale his lips are; see how his Perriwig stares with his wild passion; his hands and body tremble. Oh this Celia's a cruel Wretch.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ah, perfection of ill: Wou'd you convert your infamy? Disguise your falshood in my shroud of madness? No, no; it shall not do. Madam, all shall out, assure your self it shall.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: So handsome, so well compos'd a man: Oh heavens what pity 'tis: run, my Lord, run to the Gate, and call your Footman to fetch a Doctor! two houres in such a fit will kill him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Stay, my Lord, and hear me—I'll discover all—This Lady—

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.l: Ah, delay not a minute, as you love his life!
My Lord—away, away.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Poor Manley, thou shalt not dye for want of so small a Courtesie.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Well, Madam, What's your design in this? What new plot is contriving?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Oh heav'n! Am I thus requited? Sir, I never expected such an action from you: Was there no way to augment my misery but this?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your misery! Ha, ha, ha. Your misery!—

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: You know well enough that this is the person my Uncle designs to Marry me, and that 'tis impossible for me ever to see you, if he knows you are his Rival.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Hah, this may be true; for he has formerly told me something of
an Intrigue like this: Well, suppose this true Madam, I am sure Mr Iollyman is a person not interested in your Uncles favour, though in yours.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: In mine! That an impertinent Serenader, only accepted for the Company's sake he brought with him, shou'd have the impudence to talk thus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He protested it to me a truth, and swore your extravagant favour exceeded his hopes.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: And you believ'd it: Well, I'll take care with whom I trust my heart agen—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ugh, I can hardly believe this; yet sure these tears are real, it must be so—Come, I do believe thee, forgive me Celia; and consider how insupportable is Jealousie lodg'd in a Lovers breast.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: If I had not hit of this Plot, what shou'd we have done then? I warrant you won't believe I love you yet.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By this I do, thou hast confirm'd it in me.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: He'll come back immediately, and I wou'd not have him see you for the World; therefore be gone, I'll expect you this Evening at my Uncles.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I will not fail you Sweet, I am glad it happens thus.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!
Thus with the snowy Veil of Innocence,
Contriving Women cover their pretence;
When Women weep, look, Gallants, for surprize,
For all deceit lies drencht in wat'ry eyes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There's a Coach ready at the Park Gate, how now, where is he?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Ah! gone, gone, all my entreaties could not stay him, frighted, I believe, at my naming a Doctor; I saw him cross the Mall, but in such a strange posture, that caus'd both pity and admiration in all that beheld him▪

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Poor Iack, I see the fits of Madness are as sudden, as those of Love, and commonly work the same effects, Fate keep me from the tryal of it; for Excess in any thing is a perfect torment, especially this Modish Passion we Men so hunt after, and which is so generally admir'd, though conducing to Madness.—
sp.l: He that of Loves ripe Ioyes takes over measure,
Abates his Bliss, and loses half the pleasure.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: Scene I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Arthur, Tilbury, Jollyman and Friendlove, al. Dorel.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: URge me no more, Sir, you have my answer, my final and my punctual answer, I will proceed no further in this business; nor shall my Neece join issue with a man so wild, and so unfortunate: St Ierom's tears spilt, my treasure, my chiefest treasure lost, a blessing which this forty Years we cherish'd, snatcht from me in an instant! oh unparalleld misfortune! I say, let him forbear my house.

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.p: Well, of a Knight, and a Justice of Peace, this is the simplest man of Worship I ever saw; good Sir, let it not so nearly concern you, you shall have restitution, by St Iago I'll fell half my Estate, but Ill make you amends; What a Pox, d'ee think I ll be ungrateful?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Half your Estate! a pretty Proposition; 'sbud, Sir, the Grand Signiors Revenue would not purchase a drop on't.

sp.speaker: Ioll
sp.p: A very costly Liquor by Mahomet, I think that Turkish Oath sounds well—hah—▪

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Old Oaths are not to be despis'd, Sir, therefore by Melchizedech, which, I conceive, was well thought on, my resolutions fixt, your son shall be a stranger to my house, my daughter is not for him, tell him so; 'zlid shou'd he come here, within a Week I should have my ancient Medals of the Romans plaid off at Gaming-houses.

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.p: Sir, upon my Reputation, he knows not what belongs to a Gaming-house; alas Sir! You are ignorant of his Principles, he's Countrey bred, Sir—Countrey Learning, Countrey Manners, and Countrey Wit; 'sbodikins he knows nothing of the Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: But he may know every thing in time, Sir; and I'll harbour no person within my doors, whose future knowledge is more dangerous than his present.

sp.speaker: Ioll
sp.p: Udsbores a necessary Maxim.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Trouble your self no more, Sir, my Will is my Law; and tho' I am a Justice of the Peace and Quorum, I think my proceedings in this both necessary and judicial—My Neece is an Heiress, and there is great care requir'd in her bestowing; nor shall my Daughter match into a Family, when I give such evident proofs of my dislike. Mr Tilbury, you, as being my old acquaintance, shall be welcome to my house; but give me leave to tell you, my eyes are open'd to your sons folly, you understand me, I do not like their tricks Sir.

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.p: Tricks Sir!—I find 'tis you have your tricks Sir—But by St Iago Ill go Fee my Lawyer immediately, force shall compel what good words cannot persuade; and I've a Bag of old Harry-Groats have lay'n by me these twenty Years, which I'll scatter amongst the Gownmen, rather than be thus abusd.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth
sp.p: Old Harry Groats! What pity 'tis so meritorious an Antiquity should be so ill employ'd—is he gone?

sp.speaker: Dorr.
sp.p: Yes Sir—just turn'd the corner of the street in so hasty and discompos'd a manner, that it argues him plotting some business of importance.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Wou'd he were here agen. Now wou'd I rather his son should have my daughter, than that he should waste any of that precious money.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Let it go, let it go, there's enough to be had in Lumberstreet: But, Sir Arthur, to my present affair; since you have been so generous to deny him your daughter, I hope my address may be successful.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Troth, Sir, Hope is very necessary in this affair; and if you can but hope my daughter will like your Person and Years, as well as I like your Estate, your Hope will have as ample a Field to range in, as any mans I know.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: My Person and Years—Why, Sir, 'tis impossible she shou'd dislike it; whatever my Years are, I assure you my Imagination is but One-and-twenty.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: But, Sir, in the space of a Week, the strength of your Imagination will be worn away, and your Person will be left to the deliberate age of Eight-and-fifty a month or two over.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: No, 'tis three-months under by my faith, Sir Arthur, and what, then? With me 'tis an age of 21; Look in my face, Sir, observe how the blood mounts; here, here's your Complection, without art, fucus, or any thing—▪ Then, Sir, peruse my Person—Hah—I think I am well set—Hem—And as found as another man—Besides, I can talk well, walk well, and make Water well—which, udsbores, is as provoking a quality as any man is Master of.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Sir, in a young man I confess these are additions; but a man that has the misfortune to decline into the vail of Years, were he really Master of all this, wou'd not get credit with the World, he would not be believ'd.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Not believ'd! Sir, my actions shall give continual demonstration, I am not in the Catalogue of your infirm persons; my Back, Sir, is strong, by Body active; nor has my infirmity been so much my Foe, to abate any part of my vigour: But I can Run, Wrestle, Fight, or Play a Game at Tennis with any Spark i'th' City, and let the World rub. To confirm you, you shall see me do't—(Not believ'd!) Udsbores you shall see me Ride the Great Horse, or jump over a Stick for the King of England.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Well Sir, I will consider on't—in the mean time address your self to my daughter; come, you shall sup with me: Dorrel, if any one ask for me—I am not at leisure—be careful, and let no eye be Spectator of my Rarities without my knowledge, come Sir—

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.p: The uncertain Dice of Fate thus far runs well, and my designs are prosperous—My disguise, shrowd to my troubled mind as well as person, secures me yet from knowledge; and my eye attains the liberty to gaze at all her actions, and yet pass undiscover'd—Oh curs'd Jealousie, how crooked are thy paths!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Unconstant, and to me! by Heav'n 'tis so strange a Notion, that methinks 'tis incredible.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And why incredible? Lord how you Men are deceiv'd in your opinion! Your term your selves Princes and Lords of Nature, imagining the easie tempers of Women slaves to your nobler quality; and yet for all your pretences, to my knowledge some of you are often mistaken.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, if she be false—

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why then she's damn'd, that's one comfort however; but Madam, this extraordinary favour in you, obliges me in gratitude to a return. Shall I wait on you to your Lodging, by Heav'n I hate ingratitude? Come, Madam, what satisfaction?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Such a question to a mercenary Spirit, might perhaps be accepted under the Notion of gratitude, but you having a perfect knowledge of my quality, and obliging temper, give me leave to tell you, my Lord, 'twas very unbecoming, especially from the mouth of a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I gad I mean it cordially, and if my service—

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, y'are observd, yonder's Sir Arthur's Man from him, you may doubtless learn the truth of all, my presence will be unnecessary, therefore I'll withdraw—So, I hope this will wean him—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: This is one of her Suitors, now for a new discovery, and I'm resolv'd to be prepar'd for him—Your Lordships humble Servant—▪

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Dorel, Come hither, I've some business with thee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis too much Honour, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I long have lookt on thee as on a Man above the common Pile of Menial Servants; and since I know thee such, I dare request a secret from thy tongue to me of great importance; Come, I'll bind thee to me in golden Fetters; shall I trust to thee?—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I am your Lordships Creature, and if my ability extend to serve your Lordship, I am proud on't.
Sure he has not discover'd me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'll try thee instantly. The truth is, Dorell, I am grown jealous of my Mistriss, several Reports declare she is unconstant; and tho' I do not positively believe 'em, yet Gad I must confess they trouble me; now I know thou hast a Catalogue of all her Suitors, and know'st all her intrigues, prithee disclose 'em, am I the Man or no, or has she others?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: This is so dangerous a point, my Lord, I know not how to answer.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fear nothing, but speak to th' purpose, I'll be so much thy friend, thou shalt not need to fear the frowns of any.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My Lord, there is one Mr Manley comes hither often.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, who else?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And one Mr Iollyman; I heard her sware one night she'd marry him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very good, prithee proceed—oh perfidious Traytress.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Now has he a fretting Feaver on him. Several others there are my Lord that visit her as Pretenders, but with what success I know not, one of 'em I heard her appoint to visit her to night; and because your Lordship shall see how willing I am to serve a person of so much worth—Follow me, and I'll place you, where you shall, unseen, hear all their Courtship.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do that, I am thine for ever.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: More than that, owes Tribute to your Bounty; Come my Lord—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Can this be real, Madam?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: True as Heav'n;
I swear she is the falsest of her Sex,
Designing Love upon fallacious terms,
Without a spark of passion or desire
To possess him that Courts her—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Perjur'd Creature,
Oh Heav'n that Providence gave Man a heart
To lose in such Abyss of Treachery;
But, Madam, is there no ocular proof to be given of this?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: There is Sir, and to that purpose I brought you hither; My Chamber joins to hers, whence from a private Closet door you may hear all; one of her Suitors is now with her, and by their discourse you may soon guess the truth of her treachery; for doubtless 'twill be amorous enough, and very sutable to such an adventure.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
O Dam her! Dam her! Is this her Constancy! Madam, the
Debt of Gratitude I owe you for this discovery, is so far above my present ability—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Good Sir, no more of that—but follow me—▪

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: All her feign'd Caresses come to this! a Curse upon the Sex—Madam, I wait your leisure.

div.stage: Scene discovers L. Fickle in a Morning Gown, and Harry sitting.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: And cou'd you credit so ridiculous an Asseveration, knowing how tender my Caresses have been to ye, I thought my actions might have given you sufficient demonstration of my constancy.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: By Heav'n I never doubted it, I confess I was a little surpriz'd to hear him say he was at the expence of a six months Courtship, and within a Week more it was to terminate in Marriage. But now you have told me his intrigue with Madam Constantia, I am very sensible of the mistake▪—

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Had I not told you, I'll lay my life you wou'd ha' been jealous.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, no, 'Faith I shou'd not—jealous▪—I know I have no cause, thou art the Heav'n of truth, and in thy breast Astrea reigns and triumphs. Suspect thy Faith, what Fiend cou'd be so envious? I'll prove thy Constancy as firm as Fate, and against all defend it.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: So, I think I have carry'd matters rarely.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But, Madam, pardon me, if I presume to ask you why our interview is to be thus i'th' dark?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: 'Tis because Sir Arthur's coming often into the next Room, seeing a Light here, will be very apt to come and disturb us.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: 'Sdeath—I've ignorantly left my Sword and Gloves upon the Table there, which shou'd he come in, would infallibly discover my being here—I'll go fetch 'em immediately.—

div.stage: Enter Nurse (with a Light) in a Morning Gown.

sp.speaker: L. Fick
sp.p: How now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Oh sweet Madam—ugh—I am so out of breath, there's the basest Plot contriving—

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: A Plot! pritheewhat Plot?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Where's the Gentleman? get him into another Room, or you'll both be discover'd immediately.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: How prithee? by what means?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Madam Constantia has watch'd you all this night, with an intent to betray you; I saw her bring Mr Manley into her Chamber, I'm confident with design to place him where he may hear the discourse 'twixt you and the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Manley brought hither by Constantia! her envy now is apparent—What shall I do Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Alas! I know not—Fire the House, I think, and say you call'd him in for help.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: No, so dangerous a Remedy must not be try'd—Humm—I have it—Sit you down, and personate me, our Gowns are alike—and in the dark there can be no difference in Faces—He's in the next Room, looking for his Sword, when he comes, feign my voyce, and Caress him like a Lover; in the mean time I'll go, and with a Counterplot deceive both Manley and Constantia.
sp.l: Prosper designs, and by this Act I'll try
Which is the Witty'st False One She or I—

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Well, I've known the time when I've employ'd my self in such an Adventure with a better Will—But however I'll warrant I'll fit him with a Repertee—I am not so old, but I can Repertee as well as another, if occasion serve.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: 'Tis so dark, that igad I could hardly find the Table. Where art thou my Dear?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Here my Dear.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I have been often thinking on the products of time, and have often wonder'd how they employ'd themselves before the Deluge—When Love was like the storming of a Castle attain'd by violence, not as now, with fair words, address, and insinuation; Men were not then such Fools to kiss a Glove—fall on their knees and sigh—igad they were wiser in those dayes—

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Fie, fie, I protest you are not civil—D'ee know who I am—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: D'ee hear 'em Sir—They're yonder in th' Alcove.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I do Madam, and am sufficiently confirm'd in her treachery; but hush—let's observe.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Sir, Ill go and get a Coach to the Garden gate, that you may get away undiscover'd—I think— [Ex. Constan.
This was well plotted—

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
I protest! methinks your carriage is too Licentious, and in my opinion you treat me ill—Your Love shou'd still be cloath'd with a respect
due to my Youth and Beauty—But I vow you'r so wanton—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Very well—she'll deny this anon—

sp.speaker: Harr.
sp.p: Can any ill arrive from so much Love, I swear there cannot, Madam; your charms are ingraven in my heart, and in my soul your virtues—I die when you are absent, and 'tis your influence that raises me from death to new-born life, and makes me currant from the dross of Nature.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Give me no cause to doubt what you have said, I then shall be contented; but I protest you Men are so subject to flatter, and we poor tender young creatures are so apt to believe, that it often proves very prejudicial—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She doubts his Love—oh death—I shall want patience—

sp.speaker: Harr.
sp.p: To flatter thee—by Heav'n 'tis a thing so far from me, I hardly know its meaning: Let Parasites, such as get Bread by fawning, flatter their Patrons: Let the empty Fopp, that's sensible of some defect in Nature, and sees the little beauty in his Mistriss, flatter her to exalt it, but in me it wou'd appear a Crime unpardonable, your Lustre wants no foiles; but like a Diamond in his Native Rock, you shine without the aid of Art or Flattery.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Now by my quondam Maidenhead this is very pretty, well Sir, you shall find my heart—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And Lungs pray Heaven—wou'd she might Cough 'em out—she has catch'd cold with sitting up so late. Oh damn'd Incendiary.

sp.speaker: Harr.
sp.p: Could I live out Methusalah's long Age, or number Years with the old Patriarchs, and every day study new Themes of Virtue, I could not merit half so great a blessing; brightest of Women, fresher than the Dew that early sits on Roses—oh I'm rapt with my own happiness!

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Well, as I'm Virtuous this is fine—I see I shall not be able to hold out long—I shall grow bold with him—I hope, Sir, my Love deserves this from you, you have entire possession of my heart—and tho' I have broke my faith with all my other Suitors, I've kept it firm for you.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Sir, Sir!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Limb of the Devil—I hear her Madam, I hear her.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: You should not hear 'em Sir, pray come back, they are Lovers—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Lovers, Dam 'em—Have a little patience, I'll wait on you immediately—

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: I Swear you're uncivil, Sir, thus to disturb e'm—for heaven's sake come away—

div.stage: He turns back, sees her, and starts.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Wonder of wonders—Is there two Celia's—or, Am I in a Dream?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Yonder's a Light—Let's step in here—I fear, Sir Arthur's coming—

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: What ailes you, Sir? For heav'ns sake why d'ee stare so! Dee yee not know me!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By Heav'n I know not: Are you Celia?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: What strange questions are these, You know I am?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And, Is that yonder Celia too?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Heav'n! What a humour's this? That Celia? No: 'tis a Lady that lodges here, one that Mr. Iollyman Courts.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Young Iollyman!

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Iollyman? yes—What d'ee wonder at? if this humour hold, you need not counterfeit a Madness.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By heav'n you are right—I am mad! stupid, insensibly mad: and have been so these three hours—'Sdeath, Was ever any thing so strange as this? sure I've been enchanted; pray Madam give me leave to question yee, Where have you been all this night?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: In my Chamber—Sir—expecting you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Who told you I was here?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Constantia; I met her coming up stairs; and, seeing me, she brake into a violent laughter; and asking her the reason, she told me, she had put a pleasant trick upon you; and then fell a Laughing till she shook agen.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I'gad I have been trickt, that's the truth on't—Oh the Devil▪ Am I thus abus'd?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: This from a Woman that lov'd yee, is very strange—Who did you expect to find?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You—she told me you was in that Alcove, and plac'd me to hear you—where I have stood this half hour in the most insufferable Torture! the Agony of jealousie and despair, that 'tis impossible to express it.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p:
Me! Did you expect me there? and after all my actions, to declare my unspotted constancy; Are you still jealous, ingrateful man?—Was ever woman so unhappy? Will nothing 〈…〉
Weeps▪
make you credit me! I Swear I am the most unfortunate of Women! How has my Soul and Heart been fetter'd to you? How have I dreamt of you, and thought a look to any other man was an offence to Love? slighted the Oaths of Gallants—shun'd their presents! despis'd their persons, and refus'd their guifts all—all for you, And do you still suspect me?—Would I could be unconstant! wou'd I had the power to be so, that I might revenge my self—Oh misery! still suspected!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: If she be false, there's no such thing as truth: I'll credit it no more—Madam, I see my error, and thus low sue for pardon—'Tis my last tryal: and I will henceforth more adore thy vertues than ere I did suspect e'm; Thou art the soul of Truth, so excellently good: Nature is proud of her great work; nor will I ever be betray'd agen into the gulf of jealousie, but live blest in thy love, the Prince of all content, and dye old in thy Armes.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: You will relapse agen.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Never by Heav'n—by this kiss I'll never—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Come, Sir! the Coach—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: May return agen if it please, Madam—your servant, you see your plot han't took—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: This Devil has outwitted me—nay, in this plot, which I thought so securely laid, it was impossible to break it. Her cunning is so prosperous, that I believe Hell designs her for the onely person to wheadle Souls with:
sp.l: I'll try once more—
And if my next plot hit not right, give o're.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Here they are. I have from yonder dore, now too late, resented her treachery—Dam her! was mine a heart to play with? Was there not Fools enow to feed with hope, but she must flye me?—but I ll revenge my self immediately—

sp.speaker: Harr.
sp.p: Here's some body coming towards, let's retire my Dear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir! I have a Message first—

sp.speaker: Harr.
sp.p: Such Messages are thus to be return'd.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Ah help, help! Murder, murder—help, help—

div.stage: Enter L. Fickle with a Candle.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: What's the matter Nurse? Oh heav'ns my Lord Bellamore! and Mr. Iollyman! How came you hither at this time of night?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! What a mistake is this—Have I fought for this pippin?

sp.speaker: Harr.
sp.p: Zounds! Have I bestow'd all my Caresses and Courtship to night upon this Beldam?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Well, Sir; I shall find a time to requite your favours for all your jesting.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Gad, I thought it had been you Madam—

sp.speaker: Harr.
sp.p: And so did I by Heav'n. I durst have sworn 'twas her voice.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your thoughts were ill imploy'd, Sir, in a thing that so little concerns you: I hope you have no pretences here.

sp.speaker: Harr.
sp.p: How, Sir, no pretences! Ha's any man?—

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: 'Buz: 'Sdeath are you mad! why this [Stops his mouth. is the person my Uncle designs me to marry—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nor is this boldness pleasing, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: My Lord! for heav'ns sake what d'ee mean? Will you ruine all—This is the very Gentleman my Uncle designs for my Husband—and if he knows you are his Rival—I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Come, Madam, Whither do you run? by heav'n I'm so melancholly—without you—ha', my Lord Bellamore and Iollyman! 'Sdeath! What new intrigue's this?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: O Fate! Is he come too? What a spiteful minute is this? [Aside. Why Sir! What d'ee mean? D'ee not see my Lord there, unknown; To be he supt with Sir Arthur to night, and has chosen this Minute to accost me—Stare, stare! counterfeit your self Mad, or we are lost: Then leave the rest to me. Pray, Sir, to bed.
To bed. Fye, What mean you by this unseasonable rambling? Sir Arthur will be very angry if he knowes it. Stare! stare!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Iack Manley here at this time of night—Hark'ee Madam, What makes him here?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Sir Arthur seeing him in his mad fit, brought him hither to night, with intent to administer a potion, which he had made for Lunatick persons; and, it seems, they left his Chamber dore open, and he is got out. Look! look how he stares!

sp.speaker: Harr.
sp.p: Gad, 'tis a miracle to me to see him thus—I have often heard him say, Love is the Parent of Dullness, and Wine of Madness. Madam, How came his misfortune?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Love, Sir, Love. Passion for one Celia, a Lady i'th' Town here, an obdurate, inconstant person I have heard—and it seems she has wheadled him into this condition.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She shall be drest in Flames! Pendants of Ice shall hang at either eare, and cool her as she burnes—whiz—buz—shugh Bough—she's gone, ha, ha, ha—Ah Celia! How sweet were thy amours? Dam her! she eates Onions—and her blew veines are all but colour'd Lute-strings, in which she hangs her Cupids, Sir—Sir, I would have your Nose par'd less—adieu, adieu pop—Let me hear no more on't—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Had I not seen this▪ I should have thought it incredible, a man of the Town, and run mad for Love—by heaven 'tis above the common rate of wonders, and doubtless portends some visible Calamity that threatens the Nation—

sp.speaker: Harr.
sp.p: Madam, a word with you.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: No whispering, Sir; 'twill cause him to suspect us—you know my promise—visit me to morrow morning, and then by an unexpected choice, I shall declare the man I think most worthy of my Love,

sp.speaker: Harr.
sp.p: Enough, I will not sail. I guess the night far spent, and in slaying longer I may obstruct your rest: I'll take my leave, Madam, your faithful servant—My Lord, your Lordships devoted. He little thinks what pollicy's in this—

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Now, Am not I extreamly kind, thus to send him away, that I may have the freer discourse with you? I hope you will say this is very obliging.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I confess it weighs somewhat more then a common favour; but, Madam, I am not yet satisfied in his proceedings; his coming hither so late must be upon some design: and, how that old Woman shou'd interpose, is to me a Mistery—

sp.speaker: L. Fick▪
sp.p: Oh dull▪ dull man! Why d'ee not see 'twas by my plot? I order'd the light to be taken away, and laid her a Bait for him, purposely to keep my self free from his troublesome Impertinences—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Was that it—by heav'n 'twas a Witty one—

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Was that it? What else cou'd it be—I wonder what recompence I shall have for this care, in preserving my Love intire, I Swear my Lord you'll be ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No: by heav'n I'll heap together as much Love, and strong Imagination, as wou'd serve forty men: But, I'll be out of thy debt—prithee do not censure till the tryal is made: I'gad I'm sure I never fail'd yet—But, When shall be the day?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: To morrow, Sir! a sudden thought has so ordain'd it. Visit me in the morning, where I suppose will be the rest of my Amoretto's; and you shall see what sentiments of private passion my heart retains for you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To morrow! I am rapt with the thought on't! To morrow.
sp.l: Call up the Sun! black shades away;
Bid Phosporus go fetch the Day.
sp.p: As my friend Cowley has it: Madam, I'll be as early as the Lark; nay, by heav'n, I'm very passionate! You see your Beauties pow'r, Madam—And, I'll go and prepare my self—

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: And I'll go and think of my purpose.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Think on to morrow night—A pox on purposes,

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: You shall have reason to curse it when you know what purpose I mean—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Are they gone, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Both gone, Sir, and full of different hopes—I Swear the love I bear you makes me commit strange frailties.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh my Dearest; my heav'n of love; How shall I recompence thee? My life's service as nothing, if consider'd. When, when my Sweet?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: To morrow, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Happy accent!

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.l: You carry'd the plot so well, in counterfeiting madness,
That I were ingrateful, should I not recompence to visit
Me to morrow morning, Sir; and, by a happy choice,
Receive what you have so long sigh'd for.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Oh Transport of Delight!
By heav'n I fear I shall not live till then:
Excess of joy will kill me—Best of Women:
Best, 'twas too vilely said, thou art so good;
By heav'n thou art a Miracle—and I
The happy man elected to possess it:
Till the morning comes I will employ my self,
In thinking on thy Beauties—and then dy,
In the possession of so sweet a Joy—

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha—
That Heav'n shou'd give man so proud a heart,
And yet so little Knowledge—Silly Creature,
That talkes, and laughes, and kisses oft that hand,
That steales away its reason; As if Nature—
Had play'd the Traytor, and seduc'd the Sex,
Without the aid of Destiny, or Women.
Ah! With what pleasant ease
The Bird might be ensnar'd—Set but a wanton look
You catch whole Covyes: Nay, there is a Magick
Pertaining to our Sex, that drawes e'm in,
Tho' in the Long Vacation—And, by Heav'n,
I'm resolv'd to work my sly deceipts,
Till my revenge is perfect 〈…〉 Thus farr I've done well,
And I'll persevere in the Mistery.
Wheadle e'm to the snare with cunning plots;
Then bring it off with quick designing Wit;
And quirks of dubious meaning. Turn and wind
Like Foxes in a storme; To prey on all,
And yet be thought a Saint—Thus Queen I'll fit,
And Hell shall laugh to see a Womans Wit.

div.head: Scene, The Street.
div.stage: Enter Zechiel, Toby, Flaile, Jollyman, Linkboyes, and Musicians playing and singing.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.l: HEy! rare Boyes! rare Boyes. Done like sons of Thunder:
True heirs of mirth and jollity, upon honor we have outdone
Example in our frollick to night, the Town shall talk of us,
With admiration, and call us Children of the night; The night,
The happy night. 'Pox o' your day-debauches, the dull and insipid
Common-way of frollick. Give me the Night to roar in—

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.l: 'Sbud, well said:
The night or nothing, I say—Give me thy hand,
I love thee, Thou art a merry Wagg: I am pleas'd with't,
Udsbores I am. I thought I had a son here too,
But I see now he's grown a serious Rascal,
He never seeks good Company, such as thine is—
No matter, hand pinching, I'll be even with him,
And let the World rub.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Banter him, banter him Toby. 'Tis a conceited old Scarab, and will yield us excellent sport—go play upon him a little—exercise thy Wit—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Not I 〈…〉 uds hash—I had like to have had my head broke with his Halbert just now, for going about to exercise my wit.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.l: Come, another Song, another Song my merry Wags,
And hang pinching, I'll make a third man—hem—

lg.head: SINGS.
lg.l: And underneath the Greenwood Tree
This Youngster laid her down a,
And there he Kist her once or twice,
Sing hey derry, derry, derry, down, a.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: O brave old Signior—Flail! Sirra, Bimdog, what a pox dreaming. Sing Sirra to entertain the Company.

sp.speaker: Flail.
sp.p: I Sing, Zing, What d'ee mean, Sir! I Sing! Lord save us: alass I canno Sing, Sir, Ich was ne'r so well bred.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Whistle then you Dog, do something for Diversion—

sp.speaker: Flail.
sp.p: Whistle! by Coxbones I cannot whistle neither. Bless us, Must I never go to bed—Bless me from London, if this be the Trade.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Trade! Thou son of Assafaetida! call a Gentlemans divertive Custome a Trade. Come, all hands, wee'll go Pump the Rogue.

sp.speaker: Iolly.
sp.p: Ay, ay; a dull drowsy Rascal: Pump him I say—

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.l: A prize! a prize! Petticoates upon honour;
Stand there! come before a man of Authority—And why
Thus early my Lady of the Lake? Whither are you going.

sp.speaker: 1. Wench.
sp.p: To Hell▪ Will you follow me?

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Not I, upon honour: There I'll leave you—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: By your favour, Madam, What's a Clock?

sp.speaker: 2. Wench.
sp.p: I am sorry the pawning your Watch, Sir, forces you to Ask so necessary a Question—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: Now will this damn'd bulking Quean be too witty for me;
'O my Conscience if I shall ask her any more Questions!
Uds hash! I'll ee'n proceed to the Business, and say nothing.

div.stage: Joll. goes to the other, and she slights him.

sp.speaker: 3. Wench.
sp.p: Fy, fy, Sir! an old man and talk thus!

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.l: An old Man! 'Sbud! You'r a Whore, an old man! Call a
Gentleman, in the midst of a night Debauch old—Hem,
Hem—Sound Lungs and Heart-whole—old quoth a!

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.l: Come, upon honour, ye shall all to the Tavern with us, and
Wee'l compleat the nights debauch with Credit: But first
A Song. I know you have your parts in the last new Verses,
Made of the Nights Ramble. 'Tis a part of your Function, a
New Song is as necessary for a Town Woman, as a Sute of Knots,
Or a new Gown—Hey! strike up there!

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Happy the Man that takes delight,
In Banquetting the Sences;
That drinks all day, and then at night,
The height of Ioy commences.
With Bottles arm'd, we stand our ground,
Full Bumpers crown our Blisses;
They rore and sing the Streets around,
In Serenading Misses.
With Bottles arm'd, &c.
Pleasures thus free and unconfin'd,
No drowzy Crime reproaches;
No Heav'n to a frollick mind,
No pleasure like Debauches.
Whilst rambling thus, new Ioyes we reap,
In charmes of Love and Drinking,
Insipid Fops lye drown'd in sleep,
And the Cuckold he lies thinking.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Whil'st rambling, &c.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.l: Rarely done of all hands: come, now let's to the Tavern,
I am resolv'd to make a night on't.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.l: Well said, agen, Boy. Toth' Tavern! toth' Tavern—hah—
Merry Rascal—hang pinching. 'Sbud 'thou'rt a brave fellow—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: Come my little pignies, you and I will go and be drunk together:
Hey—you shall see me performe rare exploits, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: Nay, Gad, now my hands in, I shall pepper you with wit,
I feel it growing in my head like a Bunch of Parsenips.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.l: Agen! Igad pinch him agen; but come, of this at the Tavern,
We lose time—Strike up there—Sing. Whilst rambling.

div.stage: Enter L. Fickle in Mans Cloaths, and Silvia, Dorel at a distance.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: So, is all fit? prithee how do I look? may I pass for a Bully of the first Rate amongst Dablers in the Mystery? how sit my Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Decently I swear, and well become you; you have as masculine an Air as any Man, I mean any Man that has no more Beard than you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: This gives an end to my suspition; the Plot's unravel'd, and my late doubts have now their period—

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Away then, and be sure you miss not a tittle in the charge I've given you, but with a seign'd sigh, and a tear or two, tell Sir Arthur I went away unknown to you, and supposing it to be discontent, relating to his designs of Marriage; do this handsomly, and I'll come in person, and prosecute the rest: This habit will, I am sure, disguise me, and I intend to invite my self to another Banquet of Wit with the Suitors, ere I have done with 'em—away—a day or two's time will make all quiet—and I shall be in readiness for as many more.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Madam, I have my Lesson perfectly, and am so much your Creature, as not to dispute your Commands.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Now am I in my opinion a second Machiavil, my Wit has finish'd Works as strong and great as Hercules 12 labours! Oh I cou'd hug my self for my inventions—they are so prosperous, as if Fate meant to make my Wit a Miracle for Men to wonder at. To betray in me's a Virtue, being first betray'd. The thought of which does like an eating Canker prey on my heart and vitals. Therefore sweet Revenge Thou art my Darling. Thus I'll blind their eyes, 'Tis on the neck of Wit Revenge must rise.—

lg.l: Can this be true! oh Heav'ns what have I heard!
Is't possible she shou'd be thus affected
To him that basely so deserted her?
If so I am a Devil, and my jealousie
The sin of all Corruption—I'll redeem it,
Watch all her actions, and discover all,
Lest she shou'd lose her self in her Revenge.
'Twas well I overheard her—Happy day!
That does all former fears with Bliss repay.

div.head: Scene 2. The Street, a Tavern Bush hung out.
div.stage: Enter Bellamore, Zechiel, Toby, Jollyman, Three Wenches and Musitians drinking.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: 'Twas well my Lord your Valor interpos'd betwixt me and the danger, by Heav'n I had been stockado'd else—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am glad Sir, Fate guided me that way, and made me capable of doing you so good an office, pray how came your quarrel?

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Why one of the Rascals would needs take the wall of me, nay, tho' I told him in French I was drunk, and had a Whore with me—Was ever such an incivility? But I think I am reveng'd, for if I may believe my eye, my last full Pass pierc'd his Diaphragma— I'm sure I kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: How, kill'd him! Not so, I hope, my merry Wag, not so—

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.l: Not so, upon Honour I am sure it is so—
Whoo—Pox 'tis accounted nothing now in Term-time.
The killing a Man's no more lookt on in a Nights Debauch,
Than getting a Clap in a Mornings Ramble.
The Town's full, the Town's full.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: I hope the consequences are no worse than he makes 'em;
But udshah—my heart goes a-pit-to-pat.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Tho' I hate this Fellows impertinence, yet for diversion sake I'll make one in the Debauch to Night: Sirra, bid the Coach go home, tell Raines I have no occasion for him to Night.—

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.l: Come Musick strike up there, Damme' you sleepy Dogs,
Come, we'll have a Song and a Dance, hey—Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Will you not be pleas'd to take a private Room Sir▪

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: A private Pox Sir. [Strikes him. What I warrant you take us now for some of your serious brood of Aldermen, d'ee Sirra? But such another word, and I shall make a private Room in your Guts for this Engine here.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Sirra, you shall be hufft and cufft, and flip'd and kick'd, Sirra, if you talk of private Rooms—Now am I as valiant as a Hector, methinks I cou'd beat this Drawer into a Wicker Bottle—

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Sirra, as a Reprieve for Life, bring out the Butt, we'll have the triumph of Bacchus to Night, my Lord you shall be Spectator; now of one of my Frolicks, I invented it in Paris, for the benefit of all Lovers of the Grape, and cherishers of Burgundy, and I hope you'll speak it a faceti • us one; 'tis call'd a triumph to Bacchus, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A good Theme Sir—worthy of your Wits invention; no doubt a great piece of ingenuity.—

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.l: Come my witty Devottees of Venus,
You must be assistant here.
Hey—Drawer, where are you Sirra?
sp.stage: Enter Drawers with an empty Butt.
sp.l: Come hither Toby, thou shalt personate god Bacchus—
Give him Wreath there—and a Bumper—
Come, up, up, advance into the Throne—
So, now Ladies kneel, and pay obedience to your Emperor—
My Lord, I must beg your Lordship to bear part in the Ceremony—
There on that side, my Lord—
Drawer give every one a Glass—
Flourish Musick and drink—
Hey—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: How do I present it, ha! methinks it becomes me very well.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Look big, look a little bigger, you know the Effigie.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: By the Lord Harry I'll kiss thee for this, my Darling of the dark-Well, I am resolv'd to disinherit my Son, and adopt thee—hang pinching, I'll do't Boy, and let the World rub.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Come, now to the Song—and let all parts be ready for the Chorus.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Bacchus thou mighty Power Divine,
Great God of Mirth, and sprightly Wine,
Behold us here that Kneeling show
The Duty that we owe—
We through thy influence rejoyce,
And thus with free and chearful voyce
The Fame and Praises sing
Of Bacchus our great God and King.
'Tis Wine, 'tis Wine, that still controuls,
And Fame and Love must both strike Sail;
There lies such vigor in full Bowls,
The Fate of Princes can't prevail.
The Wreaths of great Heroes his Altar shall Crown,
Whil'st the Grave and the Prudent bow down.
When Beauty darts a smiling Beam,
But one brisk Glass takes Care away,
And yields us back the Prey:
No Fate of Love or piercing Dart
Can wound when Wine surrounds the heart;
Still guarding it from Care,
It baffles Fate, and slights the Fair.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: 'Tis Wine, 'tis Wine, &c.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Spark, let me embrace thee, 'udsbores thou art the Mirror of our Age, and hast the best principles of English Gallantry I ever saw—Ah would I were but 5-and-20 for thy sake—but come—hang pinching—'tis well it's no worse, as my friend Hearty sayes—

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: What think you my Lord? is it not Modish?—by Heav'n 'tis new, that's one good property, and I believe 'twill take very well.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, if you will take my opinion in this business, I think it an excellent Invention, and were I you, I wou'd have Books printed, that the World may not be ignorant; 'igad you have this encouragement, the Press has been troubled with matters of less consequence.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I tell you I have 200 l. a Year, I've my Lands free and unmorgag'd, and am resolv'd to keep a Miss, according to the Mode, therefore speak now, or for ever hold your peace.

sp.speaker: 1 Wench.
sp.p: But which of us would you have Sir?

sp.speaker: Tob
sp.p: Either of you—Udshash I'm a right Countrey Squire, any thing will serve my turn, if the properties be not wanting—What's your price?—

sp.speaker: 1 Wench.
sp.p: Why in truth Sir, I have had 40 s. a Week, but in kindness to a Man of your Complexion, I'll abate a Crown.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My Complexion! ah wheadling Queen—

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Come Sirra, Drawer fill each his Glass. Hey—Let the World rub, and let's have t'other Song.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Zong quoth a—Lord zave us a Zong—pray, pray good folks—pray—oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: How now Bandog▪ what makes you howl thus? ha!

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Howl! by Coxnowns you'll howl too, if you stay longer; y'have kill'd a Mon yonder, he that you quarrel'd with about your Crack there, 'slid she have a good mind to crack her for't, and God save his Soul they think he's dead: The Constable, and a Regiment of Beggars, I mean Bilbo's, are searching for you, and just coming up the street, uds-diggers up you go, if they can catch ye. Oh that ever the ancient Family of the Tilburies should come to such disgrace!

sp.speaker: 2 Wench.
sp.p: Nay then, this is no time for Merchandizing.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Malicious Fortune, Heav'n what shall I do, if I am taken, I shall certainly be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pox, not for killing a Man in Term-time, Sir, you know the Town's full.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Hang'd! Heav'n defend, my merry Wag, is't come to that? Hang'd! Gentlemen your Servant, I've a little earnest business.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, leave not your Friends in adversity, for my part I'm resolv'd to stick to't, if we are hang'd.—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: If we are hang'd quoth a? Ah Lord! the very word has put me into an Ague.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If we do miscarry Sir—why let the World rub as you say.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you need not fear, you are a Lord, you'll come off well enough, 'tis we shall stretch for't; udshash nothing vexes me, but that I cannot stay to perform my bargain with Mrs Iuniper there.
Hark, they come, the Devil take the hindmost.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: And so say I.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Dam 'em! Are they gone? What Scarabs are these, to trust a Tavern security beyond a Sword—What Sirra are you creeping away too? turn back, and help to defend you Dog—or—

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: O Lord Sir! I defend Sir!—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fight Sirra, and fight valiantly too, or by this Steel—

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Well Sir, I will, I will, oh what will become of me!

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Come my Lord, have at 'em, since it must be so, here's old Madge has not seen Sun these 20 Years, shall be scowr'd in some of their Guts, rather than I'll be taken; udsbores I have been valiant in my time.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I must quickly dispatch, for fear of a disappointment with my Corinna—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh here they are, Caitiffs, Rogues, Murderers, down▪ down with 'em my Men o' Midnight, fall on in the Kings name, fall on—

div.stage: [They fight, Constable and Watch are beaten off.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: No hole, ne'r a corner to creep into? This is the worst contriv'd house I ever saw. Hangd did he say? Marry Heav'n defend, I am too raw a Bully to venture hanging yet—oh well remember'd ifaith—heres the Butt, the Throne of Baccbus, as Zechiel calls it; this will be a rare place to secure my self in [gets into the Butt] the Devil's in 'em if they search here—I'll stay till the Cry is over, and then home to my Lodging; I love a Debauch, till it comes to Fighting; but then, methinks, it grows troublesom—Hark, here they come, now close like a Coney in a Burrow.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why Neighbors we were mistaken, these were none of those that hurt the Man I am told, 'twas two Brothers, and that they were dog'd to this Tavern. Come, come—they must be here still—let's in, and see—

div.stage: Enter Zechiel above in a Baloony.

sp.speaker: Zech
sp.p: Was ever poor Night-walker in such distress? What shall I do? They are searching within, and the damn'd Rogues are so curious in the discovery, that they miss not an Anger-hole; I found this Ladder of Ropes upon a Shelf, but dare not venture down yet, for fear some prying Rascal shall snap me between Earth and Heav'n—'Sdeath I'll creep into this Bush, it may be this may secure me— [Gets upon the Tavern Bush. Hah! upon Honour I grow chearful, this is so Modish a Device, that I've great hopes of good success—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: They're all gone in, and now I'm in a Tub of Troubles about vent'ring out; if some of 'em should watch at the Gate, I shou'd be snapt—if snapt—hang'd—Udshash, my stomach cannot relish that word—Yet I'll couch a little longer, and see what will come on't—

div.stage: Enter Tilbury drunk, with a Torch.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Here comes a Man with a Eight—now sit close—

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.p:
A Son of a Whore to question a Man of 1500 l. a Year, and
dispute the Family of the Tilburies, by St. Iago he deserves to be mortifi'd—Constable—What's a Constable, to a Man of Worship! a Man of drunken reeling Worship▪ a Worm! a Scarab! 'tis fit he should be Carbonado'd. Let's see, where am I? What Tavern's this? oh 'tis the Rose, I'll take another dose of Sack here, and then—home—ho—within there Drawer, gives a Cup o' Sack here—

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Ah Lord! 'tis my Father—and drunk as a Wheel-barrow, I shall be found out, for he holds his Torch so high, that any one that comes by must needs see me.

div.stage: [Takes Orange-peals out of his Pocket, and throws at Tilbury.

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.p: Why Rascals, Poltroons—Sons of Popinjayes, what d'ee mean, hah Dare you affront a Man of Quality—I mean a Man of Countrey Quality—Hah Puppies, by St Iago I'll break all the Windows—I'll teach you to be civil-now, now—cannot I find e'r a stone. This is the great enormance of this City—here's Wenches in abundance, but not a stone to throw at a Dog—no matter—I'll set fire on your Bush, 'tis all one—I'll mortifie your Owls Nest by St Iago.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Oh! I shall be burnt! [Offers to burn the Bush. Why Father, Father, I'm here! I'm here! Your Son! Your hopeful Son—Oh Lord if I cry out too, I shall be hang'd—What shall I do? Fire! Fire! Fire!—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
How now! What's here one going to fire the house? Awa •
▪ away with him to the Lodge; here's fine work indeed! Come bring him away, stay some of you here and watch, the rest must be hereabouts—

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: But is't possible Neighbours this house should be haunted, and yet Folks live in't!

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: Possible? as sure as you are there Neighbours. They say the Devil appear'd to 'em every Night in the likeness of a Hog.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Lord bless us Sirs! a Hog! but see what the Devil can do.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: Set down the Lanthorn Patch, and come let's sit down on this Butt—I'll tell you the Story—

sp.speaker: 3 Watch.
sp.p: Ay come, silence ho, let's hear Neighbour Cobble—

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: Why look you Sirs, one Winter-night the Maid here sitting up late in the Kitchen, and busie about her Houshold affairs—who should come in at the Window but this Hog—

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: So!

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p:
And you must know the Devil's a cunning Hog, when occasion serves kept such—such a grunting and shuffling, and jumping, that the poor Wench was even out of her wits; she wou'd have pray'd,
but her memory being very short, and her Prayer-book out of the way, she could not. In short, Sir, this Hog, or this Devil, er this Devil of a Hog, for'ts all—having thrown down several Pewter Dishes, and swallow'd a whole Porridge-pot of Brewis—takes me his way into the Cellar—there makes such a wrack among the Butts and Bottles—such havock among the Glasses— [Tob. puts out the Candle in the Lanthorn. How now, who puts out the Candle there?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ugh! Ugh! Ugh!—

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Oh it comes! it comes! the Devil, the Devil—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Udshash! this Ugh, Ugh, was a rare invention, [Tob. comes out. I think I have outwitted the Rogues: Now give me a Man that can help a danger at a pinch, for tho' I say it, Machiavil was an Ass to me at a nights intrigue; but I'll away, for fear of insurrections—

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: That was Toby's voice, I believe he's gone; what the Devil was't scar'd the Watchmen so—No matter now, the Coast is clear—I'll venture down—so— [Gets down the Ladder. Upon Honour I have been severely frighted to Night: But the uncertain Fate of a Night-walker feldom meets better success—
sp.l: I have escap'd two eminent dangers, Burning and Hanging,
The thought of which has made me as dull as a rifl'd Cully.
Thus with the Brawny Crew of Suburb Roches,
We swim the Brackish Ocean of Deboches,
Without the Sense of Honour or Reproches.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter Sir Arthur, Silvia, Arbella, Constantia.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Come, come, I say, there's a trick in't, some cunning scurvy lewd design, I know it; have I not foster'd her with tenderness? and before she could write Woman, bred her carefully! What cause has she then to desert my house? Answer me that, what cause?

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.l: Only fear Sir, you should match her against her Will,
Heav'n knows I know no other cause.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: No, no, there must be more in't, 'twas your pleasure Mistriss often to quarrel with her, it caus'd your envy to see her so belov'd—hah—But bring her agen, and quickly too, or see my face no more, out of my doors, by Iacobs Pantible—a Relique of Renown'd memory: Thou art no more my daughter, unless my Neece return—

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Indeed Sir Arthur you are a little too severe in this, for I am confident Madam Constantia knows nothing of her going, she alwayes kept her intrigues from her knowledge, and consequently this, being, it seems, of more importance than any of the rest; what her design is Heav'n knows, but a day or two's time will doubtless discover all.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Madam Arbella, you are one I respect, your Father Sir Andrew Swipplethrop is my intimate good Friend, a Man I love and honour; and by St Augustines Night-cap—Madam Arbella you are welcome to my house, but seek not to defend an ill Argument—I say once more there's a trick in't—and give me leave, Madam, I will persevere in my justice—therefore Minion look to't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir, there is three Gentlemen below, Suitors to Madam Fickle, that desire admittance—

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Conduct 'em up, I hope here's some discovery.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Though I was ignorant, Sir, you were my Rival, I thought I had known you for a Gentleman, one that wou'd not have carry'd a design under the disguise of counterfeit madness; but assure your self Sir, such an injury shall require satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And have it, my Lord, when you dare demand it: all falshood I deny; nor can I condemn my self with carrying on a Love intrigue with policy.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: 'sDeath! I see I am baffled at last, these are two of her Suitors—I, it seems, the third; but I hope her choice will dissipate all doubts—

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: My Lord and Gentlemen, your humble Servant, may I request to know what bus'ness brings you hither so early?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I suppose my business is not unknown, I come Sir Arthur, to pay my devotion to the charming Corinna.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And I mine to the glorious Cleio.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And I the particular tender of my heart to the adorable Celia.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Corinna! Cleio! Celia! They are names of Antiquity, I confess—But for Heav'ns sake express your selves more largely Gentlemen, I know none of the persons.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Now the Plot begins to be discover'd, now we shall know all.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Prithee do but observe the alteration of countenances, oh this was a subtle Devil!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Neece, Sir Arthur, the rich Widow—I have had the honour to be long interest'd in her favour, and she commanded me to wait on her this morning, and promis'd publickly to make choice of me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By Heav'n she promis'd to make choice of me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Nay gad she promis'd to make choice of me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Was ever such insufferable impertinence? Sir Arthur, I protest by my honour, all I say is true; and by virtue of her premeditated choice and election, I am the Man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Death! What impudence is this? I say, by virtue of her choice, I am the Man.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Hell and Furies! I say I am the Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Hey day! What are all of ye the Men? By the Threshold of Mahomet's Temple, this is very fine! Has she a tripartite Husband, a threefold Father of Children? But hark ye Gentlemen, let us come nearer to the business; for as far as I can perceive, you have mistook the house—Here are no Chio's, nor Celia's, nor Corinna's under my roof, I can assure ye. 'Tis true, I had a Neece, a Widow, and such a Fortune as you describe—who is this day gone, I think, to seek her Fortune—h • r name is Fickle—sure she cannot be the person you seek after?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis so! We are all most finely gull'd, I find it! oh! 'sdeath, now could I eat my flesh for madness, dull Blockhead, not to perceive her Wheadling.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Fickle is her name; Dam her, she has been fickle enough I see—oh Hell! Hell! Were ever hopes so frustrated? 'Tis plain now she has entertain'd us all with equal Caresses, and by taking a several name, has thus long kept us ignorant!—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sure there must be some Plot in this, Sir Arthur, pray be particular in the Narration—is she certainly gone Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Why, Sir, upon my Honour, and the Honour of our Family, I protest Sir—she is certainly gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: The Devil go with her Sir,—oh confusion seize her, after all my hopes, and fears, and doubts, am I thus abus'd?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Oh Heav'n! Was it possible your Lordship shou'd be so deceiv'd? Nay, by a person that shou'd ha' been proud of the honour she receivd in the Amours of a Man of Quality, who was unsensible of any beauty but the charms of Corinna, nothing cou'd penetrate but the eyes of Corinna! Nor nothing appear attractive, but the Person and Mein of Corinna!—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
I protest Sir I pity you, Heav'n knows how constant you have been—how ador'd Celia dreamt of Celia, sigh'd for Celia! Mourn'd
out the tedious Night in meditations, and visited the light with thoughts of Celia, and now to have so strange a Metamorphosis, an ungrateful Fickle instead of a constant Celia, by Heav'n 'tis great Tyranny in Fortune—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Well Madam, well!

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Sir Arthur, your Servant, permit a stranger somewhat interest'd in your present affair, the liberty of speaking a word or two.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Sir, any Man that wears the presence of Gent. has liberty to express himself here—

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Then briefly and boldly thus—My Lord and Gentlemen—I know you better than you imagine, you are all Pretenders to my Lady Fickle, a person to whom my private inclinations have been long devoted, and having last Night the honour of kissing her hand, she in tears told me, she had deserted Sir Arthur's house, only to be rid of your troublesom impertinences; she also did me the favour to desire me to give you this assurance, That she hated you all three, and her former proceedings with you, have been only to divert herself with your ceremonious Addresses.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: Sure 'tis impossible a Woman shou'd be such a Devil? Dare you prove this?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Dam him—this is the impudentst young Hector I ever met with.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Hark ye, dare you fight Sir?

sp.speaker: L. Fick
sp.p: Yes Sir, with you if you dare Sir! Fight! Blood of the Heroes, d'ee question it—There's my Glove—I'll sight you all three, appoint your place and time.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The Soul of a Gyant by Heav'n, a very Devil in decimo sexto.

sp.speaker: L. Fick
sp.p: I scorn to win a Lady of her perfections, with the loss but of a drop of blood, a River full I say, my veins drawn dry, and on the active gore fierce atoms darting to win my Love through streams of Death and Horror. I'll bathe my Lips in gore, kiss bleeding Wounds, cleave Helmets, stand a Breach, and dare a Cannon, divide a Heart in two, hah! hah!—'tis done. Soul of Belona, I'll exhaust a Flood, turn Earth to Chaos, Oceans into Blood. Consume your timorous cringing Amorists, that would possess their Heav'n, but dare not bleed for't. Blood is my Province, therefore with you all am I resolv'd to fight—A single Man's too poor for my Revenge; All, all I say, and all at once, 'tis base else.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is the daringst young Rogue I ever saw, I must dash his hopes—Hark'ee young Huffing Sir, no more of this here, follow me, you shall find one of us sufficient to cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: All or none by Heav'n, I will not fight else—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Now is the time, and this mysterious Plot shall be no longer hid—fie, fie my Lord—I thought your Lordship cherish'd too much honour ever to draw your Sword against a Woman!

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: A Woman!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Look on her well, Sir Arthur, My Lord and Gentlemen, d'ee not know her? Nay, Madam, blush not, all must out—You must be discover'd. This is the very person you are speaking of, my Lady Fickle! your Cleio Sir! your Celia! and your Corinna, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: By Pharoah 'tis the same, I know her now. Why how Neece!

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: Discover'd! and i'th' end of all my Plots: what Devil told this Fellow my designs—Well Uncle—'tis I.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: What in your Masquerading habit, Madam? if I may presume, what intrigue to night are you designing for?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: 'Tis frustrated my Lord, you might have known else.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ungrateful Creature! Was I so desertless? Was my hearts passion so far wanting merit, to deserve this return?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Was I not worthy of your favor?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And was my heart too base to be your slave?

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: By Heav'n, no; all your deserts are boundless, and I am far unworthy your addresses; and since I am discover'd, you shall know why I have us'd you thus. I lov'd, and was betray'd, and for this cause swore a Revenge on all that should love me. To make it plainer to ye I am marry'd. My husband fir'd with jealousie, forsook me to spend his time in Travel; since I have liv'd a Widow in opinion, and wheadled many Suitors, but lov'd none.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Why then your Husband lives!

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: I know not Sir, I have not seen him since.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes Sir, he lives, and lives to bless the hour he took up this disguise—oh my Sweet—Consider humane frailty, and forgive my Crime of too much Jealousie.

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.p: My dear Friendlove! Can this be true? Am I then once more blest with thy Caresses?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Hey Dorel metamorphiz'd to Mr Friendlove, by Melchizedech this is strange!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Marry'd! Gad I have spent my time very finely well! if ever I trust a Widow agen, may I wear Horns like Acteon, and seek for a Patrimony in terra incognita.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
I swear I have been cruel to thy Virtue, but my whole life shall sue to make amends; and my noble Lord, and you Gentlemen, whatever
Presents on this Ladies behalf have been receiv'd, shall be return'd with ample satisfaction, and since espousing her perfections, I am bound to have a particular interest in her actions: If any one here holds himself wrong'd, my person shall give him the acknowledgment he demands, and my Sword the satisfaction of a Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir! I hope you think I dare fight—and refuse not through fear—but since I see she had some reason for what she did, my particular resentments are not worth a quarrel: My thoughts now bowing down to this shrine of beauty.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And mine to this. Madam! Can you forgive—

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: 'Twere an excellent revenge to use you as my Lady Fickle did, I swear my Lord you have deserv'd it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We have all fallings, Madam, you must pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: I like this well. I like this well: win her and wear her: Mr. Manley, I like your Person and Estate well. By King Pharoab I 'em very merry, come, wee'll have a Dance.
sp.stage: Enter Constable and Watch with Jollyman. Tilbury, Zechiel, Toby.
sp.p: How now, What's here Mr Iollyman▪ and my old Friend Tilbury indurance—How came this Friend? hah!

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: An't please your Worship! these are the Gentlemen that wounded the Man last night, and they got from us once, but we catcht um again; and we took this other firing a house.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Well, leave 'em with me, I'll be Ball for their appearance to morrow—I am resolv'd nothing shall hinder my mirth to day—Mr. Tilbury and Mr Iollyman, I have heard of all your frollicks last night, both yours and your Sons. Let it be so no more: for the present all shall be well—But there is no hopes of my daughter now—she's bestow'd—

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Since she's bestow'd; God give her Joy. I'll cherish my self with a merry Song and a Fidle, and hang pinching, let the World rub.

sp.speaker: Tilb.
sp.p: My Son's unmarry'd, and the Family of the Tilburies thus disgrac'd—By St. Iago, I'l take post and away for Salisbury immediately—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: And so will I. Udshah—if these distasters belong to Men of parts, as yee call 'em—give me a Country life—for though there's less wit, there's more security.

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.p: Infamous, impertinent! Canst thou repugne the pleasures of a Debauchee! through the apprehension of a walking Nightrap, and a guilded Truncheon, with the City Armes on't—Upon honour thou art a Libel to my Fame, and unworthy to break a Glass in my society.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p:
Udshahh, I might ha bin hang'd in your society for all that, but
that Fortune was my Friend, and reserv'd me for the future benefit of my Family—

sp.speaker: Zech.
sp.l: Hang'd! A man of parts! An honest Nightwalker hang'd!
Intollerable Impudence! no Sir—assure your self no such▪
Fate attends us Brothers of the Bottles—a Stockado, a
Gentile thrust through the Lungs or so, might have
Happen'd—but no hanging, Brother Bullfinch: no hanging.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Come, come, a word to the wise is sufficient—I have resolv'd a reformation—I rellish not your Stockado's not I, nor is a gentile thrust through the Lungs, as you terme it, so agreeable with my Nature to persevere. In brief, Sir, I am converted: I will into the Country immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Come, come, embrace and be friends, I am in a good humour, and by Melchizedech—strife shall be a stranger to my house, to day: so, so; all, all well—and though you are not partners in this Wedding, you shall be merry at it—and let the World rub, as my old Friend here sayes—go call in the Fidlers there—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Come, my dear sweet, and let us loose our selves
In Loves Embraces. This is a happy day

sp.speaker: L. Fick.
sp.l: Through crooked paths, dark plots, and wayes obscure,
Revenge still roves, to make it's action sure.
I have been false to night, and purchast hate,
But Ladies, on your smiles depends my fate:
Let me then gain one happy glance from you,
And th'Witty False One shall be ever True.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: ANd now to you Gallants that smiling sit,
And with insipid Votes infest the Pit,
Because the Play was by a Stranger Writ;
The Poet sayes, he knowes his Merit's small,
And trembles at the thought of a Caball;
But since a Bully in his Play I was,
I am resolv'd a Champion in his Cause:
Therefore let him that boasts of too much strength,
Appoint the place, and send his Rapiers length:
A barb'rous Critick shall not walk the Street,
Nor from this moment dare to censure Wit,
By Heav'n I'll pepper you if once we meet.
You smile, and perhaps doubt my want of skill,
But I'll revenge it, Blood and Death I will.
I must confess there is a safer way,
You may walk safely if you'll like the Play;
But else, if you your Censures raise anew,
Fate sends his Darts abroad, Blood must ensue.
Let him that on that Basis honour builds,
Meet me to morrow in Lambs-Conduit- Fields,
There he shall find a Woman now turn'd Bully,
Has power to turn a Critick to a Cully.
